column2: 2019 “Within the last 18 months
column3: someone said R. Kelly had a good song for me. I said no.” John Legend on Kanye West
column4: political music and morality in art. In January
column5: John Legend drew widespread praise as the most prominent musician to speak out against R. Kelly’s decades of sexual-assault allegations in Lifetime’s much discussed “Surviving R. Kelly” documentary. The reaction was further proof that even aside from his own music
column6: the 40-year-old has a knack for getting people to look squarely at what matters. It’s an odd gift
column7: given Legend’s air of imperturbability
column8: and one often expressed in more playful ways
column9: as anyone who follows his wife Chrissy Teigen’s frequently viral social media accounts knows. But now Legend’s calm-in-the-storm charisma can be both seen and heard in the video for his new single
column10: “Preach
column11: ” a gospel-influenced cry against political inaction. In it the singer appears as a pastor at a protest rally. Amid the smoke and riot gear
column12: it’s Legend’s righteous quietude that lingers in the mind. Which is not an accident. “Part of what I’ve been able to do
column13: ” Legend says
column14: “is put a sympathetic face on some radical actions.” You’ve said
column15: in previous interviews
column16: that people in the arts are probably more inclined toward empathy than others. How do you square that belief with how so many in the entertainment world
column17: for so long
column18: implicitly condoned the behavior that people like R. Kelly and Harvey Weinstein have been accused of?1 Even though I think artists are more geared to be empathetic
column19: people ignore evil behavior when it comes with success and power and quality art — R. Kelly and Harvey Weinstein are responsible for some exceptional art.People were willing to look the other way until it really smacked them in the face. Have you ever made a moral decision to not work with someone? I was offered songs by R. Kelly! Within the last 18 months
column20: someone said R. Kelly had a good song for me. I said no. Why do you think the music industry hasn’t had the same degree of #MeToo reckoning that the film business has? It’s not less misogynistic. Clearly not. But if you look at who’s gotten in trouble in the movie business
column21: it’s been Harvey
column22: and his victims were famous; they’re the perfect victims as far as publicity goes. Whereas in the music business
column23: a lot of this might have happened on the road with fairly anonymous people as victims. A girl on tour in Oklahoma City is not the same as Gwyneth Paltrow. There’s an imbalance. In the case of R. Kelly
column24: did his targeting of young black women complicate things? Jim DeRogatis2 said
column25: years ago
column26: that reporting on R. Kelly showed him that nobody matters less in society than young black women. When victims don’t have status
column27: their victimhood often isn’t as valuable as other people’s. And in R. Kelly’s situation
column28: that was combined with a reflex in the black community to rally around our men
column29: who are often the subject of unfair prosecution. But we’ve got to reconsider that dynamic when it comes to protecting victims of sexual abuse
column30: because some of the perpetrators are going to look like us. I was just looking at your Twitter mentions
column31: and people were calling you hypocritical for speaking out against R. Kelly while also having participated in a tribute to Elvis Presley
column32: who had a relationship with a 14-year-old. Is there any validity to that line of argument? There’s people saying
column33: “Here’s a white guy who did this
column34: and you weren’t as hard on him as you were on R. Kelly.” People think they’re being pro-black by saying that
column35: but they’re not. What they’re really saying is that they want their guy to be free at the expense of these black girls they don’t care about. I’m not the morality police
column36: and I’ve had my own failings
column37: but at some point you’ve got to draw a line. I feel like a reasonable line would be not working with R. Kelly. What’s a personal failing of yours? We’ve all been dishonest. We’ve all been unfair. We’ve all taken advantage of the fact that we’re powerful. Last year you exchanged some texts with Kanye West
column38: which he then posted online
column39: criticizing his support of President Trump.3 You told him that he had the power to change people’s minds in favor of the president
column40: which is a position you’re obviously against. But whose mind do you think is being changed about Donald Trump by Kanye West? Who is that person? Honestly
column41: after I said it
column42: I was like
column43: “I’m not sure Kanye’s going to change many minds.” I think it’s more that he might make a certain person feel prouder about having the pro-Trump opinion. Do you and Kanye often have discussions about these things? We’ve had them. I’ve given my analysis of why Kanye thinks the way he does about Trump: He sees himself in him. Has that analysis been confirmed by Kanye? Yes
column44: through the conversations we’ve had. He sees that underdog attitude; he sees the simple marketing message
column45: and he’s excited by it. There’s a lot they have in common
column46: attitude-wise. Kanye has openly said he wants to run for president. Do you ever think it’s provocation for its own sake with him? Kanye’s thinking about everything he does
column47: but I don’t think he’s secretly like
column48: “I’m just doing this so people will talk about me.” I think he’s being honest. “Preach” is a protest song. What’s the political function of a song like that in 2019? It’s supposed to do what art does: make people think and feel. I don’t look at it like
column49: “I want this to lead specifically to that.” There’s got to be a lot more than a song to lead to someone’s doing something. So what compelled “Preach”? It was brought to me by some other writers
column50: Greg Kurstin and Sarah Aarons
column51: and I ended up kind of rewriting it from my own perspective. I was thinking of people like Emma González and the kids down in Parkland. We go through this ritual where politicians act like all they can do is hope and pray that a school shooting won’t happen again. I wanted to make a statement against that kind of passivity. It’s one thing for someone like Emma González
column52: who has experienced a traumatic event
column53: to be moved to political activism
column54: but what gives you hope that enough people who haven’t had firsthand experience won’t stay complacent? I think back to what all of us supporters did last year with the Florida Rights Restoration Coalition.4 For decades
column55: people with felonies on their records were not able to vote
column56: and the threshold for passing that bill was
column57: like
column58: 60 percent. And it happened! So what gives me hope is that I’ve been involved in campaigns that worked. I’ve seen it. To what extent can art make people more empathetic? Is there an album you can point to and say it changed your thinking about a specific subject? I can’t say that about an album. I have seen the power of film to inspire action. And news coverage — the fact that cameras show up. Black Lives Matter would not have happened without cellphone footage. That’s not the same as creating a film
column59: but visual media have spurred people to action. What’s an example of a film that spurred you to action? That’s a good question. Books definitely have done that. “The New Jim Crow” by Michelle Alexander got me excited about mass incarceration. I wouldn’t have started FreeAmerica5 unless I’d read that book. Have you gotten any pushback about your move
column60: over the last few years
column61: away from strictly personal songwriting and toward more politically informed music? Well
column62: my biggest hit was “All of Me” in 2014
column63: and I haven’t had as big a hit since. But I probably never was going to. So it’s hard for me to say that being more open in public about my politics and what I feel needs to change has had a financial effect
column64: because we — everyone — sell fewer units now. Clearly people know that I’m on the left: Breitbart and some of these conservative outlets like to talk about me. I’m sure there are Americans that think
column65: John Legend is a political enemy. But those people probably weren’t buying my music anyway. Aside from declining sales
column66: what changes have you seen in the music business? I’m still old school in the sense that I think about an album as a body of work that is supposed to endure as a body of work. So maybe I’m out of pace with where the fans are
column67: but it’s hard for me to deprogram and put out a random song here and there. What about as a listener? What changes have you heard? I’ll listen to successful albums that have great beats but very little when it comes to hooks. I don’t understand what would make you not want a hook. If there’s nothing to hook you — I don’t know. What are the fundamental differences in the way musicians like yourself
column68: working in the R & B tradition
column69: make music versus the way it was happening in
column70: say
column71: 1975? Up through the ’80s
column72: people were playing actual instruments. The musicianship wasn’t as programmed as it is now. Since the blurring of the lines between hip-hop and R & B
column73: the arrangement and production for R & B have taken on a lot of the characteristics of hip-hop. I think we’ve lost some of the musicality that we used to have in R & B. Are you comfortable with that shift? I’ve had fun working with hip-hop producers who use samples and drum machines. You can make great music that way
column74: but sometimes you lose something when it’s just that. Even when I’ve worked with hip-hop producers
column75: I would often layer live instruments on top of samples. I was uncomfortable feeling like the sound was all synthetic. I appreciate a lot of current music but some of it I’m like
column76: “I will never understand why this is successful.” But I thought that way in the ’90s too. When I was a teenager
column77: there was plenty on the radio where I thought
column78: “This is crap.” Do you ever feel a conflict between being so embraced by an industry — you’ve got the EGOT6 — that plays a part in the systems that you also criticize politically? One of my friends texted me the other day because I had retweeted someone who was talking about the problem of cash bail; that’s an issue I’ve donated a lot of money to. My friend was basically like
column79: “This is pretty radical what you’re saying.” But I don’t believe that what I think is radical. We’re the most incarcerated country in the world. That should be considered radical. Police are allowed to shoot unarmed black men in the street. That’s radical. Obviously I’m participating in capitalism. I do sponsorship deals with major corporations. I’m not radical in some ways
column80: but remedies for mass incarceration shouldn’t be considered crazy. It should be considered crazy that we have mass incarceration in the first place. So you don’t feel any conflict between your political beliefs and your work? There is a natural tension
column81: and I don’t think it’s meaningless. I just try to make a case for my political beliefs in a way that should make sense. But I was thinking about the central question you asked me at the beginning
column82: whether socially conscious music changes behavior. I don’t think it changes a person’s point of view from one thing to another
column83: but it can galvanize people already on your side. “Glory” put me on the Oscar stage
column84: 7 where I could talk about mass incarceration with millions of people watching. It wasn’t the only thing
column85: but I think my getting involved in that conversation helped move it a bit to the left. How has your relationship with someone like Chrissy
column86: who’s so popular and beloved on social media
column87: altered the trajectory of your career? It’s changed it a lot. “All of Me” wouldn’t have existed without our relationship and that song put me on a higher career plane. Then there are people who enjoy our relationship
column88: 8 and that has a halo effect on everything we do. Brands buy into it. A lot of deals that we end up doing are done with the knowledge that our profile is raised because we’re together. What’s your hunch about why the public is so interested in you two? Part of it’s because Chrissy is who she is. She’s authentic. No matter who she would’ve been with
column90: she would be interesting and she would be compelling to follow. But her being married to someone who’s also famous and whose biggest song is about her heightened our profile. It’s like my music set a precedent for us being more known
column91: and then once people actually paid attention to her on social media —— That was the rocket fuel. Yeah
column92: and people get the sense she’s one of them. She gets to be at the Oscars and these rarefied spaces as their proxy. And she doesn’t take it too seriously. She shows more quirks online than most people. Through our interaction online
column93: my fans get to see a fun side of me that may not come out in my music. If it weren’t for her
column94: I’d probably engage more conservatively online. You’ve been a professional musician since the early 2000s. But is it right that when you were younger
column95: you briefly worked as a management consultant? Not briefly. It was three years. That was my first job. I went to the University of Pennsylvania and graduated with good grades. A lot of my friends were applying to management-consulting firms and getting the best salaries coming out of school. So I thought maybe I should check it out. Please tell me you used the name John Legend as a business consultant. I did not. My name is John Roger Stephens. John Legend is a stage name. I do own the trademark
column96: though. Back then I knew I wanted to do music
column97: but I also knew music might not pay my rent. I figured I could work during the day as a management consultant and do music at night. So I applied to both McKinsey and Boston Consulting Group
column99: and got hired at BCG. They offered me $50
column100: 000 a year and a signing bonus. My dad never made that much in a year
column101: ever. Your dad was a tailor
column102: right? His full-time job was as a factory worker. He and my mom would do alterations for our neighbors and friends to supplement their income whenever there’d be a plant shutdown or he got laid off. Did anything you learned as a consultant apply to your music career? It can’t hurt to understand how to deal with executives. I developed that acumen for three years. After that point I had to decide whether to go to business school in order to be able to continue in consulting. I was like
column104: I’ve got to focus on music. I haven’t looked back. David Marchese is the Talk columnist for the magazine. This interview has been condensed and edited for clarity from two conversations.  June 28

column1: ---split---4.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/22/realestate/buying-abroad-with-a-logo.html---split---Supported by A growing number of home buyers are choosing to live in corporate-branded communities
column2: with companies from Marriott to Porsche ready to greet them. By Marcelle Sussman Fischler After 16 years of hauling suitcases to the Four Seasons Resort Nevis
column3: Ivan and Ann Highley-Gergel of Philadelphia no longer need to pack for vacations at the Caribbean island resort. About a year ago
column4: the Highley-Gergels paid around $3.5 million for a furnished
column5: four-bedroom villa that comes with a pool and a cottage and is operated by Four Seasons
column6: allowing them to keep the bathing suits
column7: flip-flops and tennis rackets at their otherwise turnkey vacation home. “It is wonderful not to have to put bags in the hold” of an airplane when they head south
column8: said Dr. Highley-Gergel
column10: a psychiatrist
column11: in a telephone interview from the island residence where he and his wife are spending a month this winter. The Highley-Gergels had sworn they would never buy a vacation home because of “the hassle
column12: ” but the convenience of buying at a branded development convinced them otherwise. From their private house
column13: they have access to all the resort’s facilities
column14: plus 24-hour security
column15: room service
column16: home maintenance and weekly cleanings. “We originally came here because we loved the Four Seasons
column17: ” Dr. Highley-Gergel said
column18: adding that the couple “was looking for somewhere with a kids’ club
column19: ” for their two younger sons
column20: then 5 and 7. The Highley-Gergels are among a growing number of Americans buying residences in brand-name resort properties
column21: mostly in the Caribbean and Latin America. Elsewhere around the world
column22: international buyers are snapping up easy-to-lock-up-and-leave
column23: high-rise residences under hotel banners like Mandarin Oriental
column24: Marriott
column25: Ritz-Carlton and W
column26: in cities from London to Barcelona to Bangkok. According to a Knight Frank “Global Branded Residences — 2019” report
column27: branded residences are “growing exponentially and can now be found in almost every major city and major holiday destinations
column28: ” with more than 400 mostly hotel-branded residences in 60 countries. The Four Seasons
column29: which opened its first homes in 1985
column30: in Boston
column31: manages about 4
column32: 000 residential units at 41 properties in 19 countries. In the next five years
column33: its portfolio is expected to grow to more than 7
column34: 000 homes
column35: said Paul White
column36: president of residential at Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts. More than 80 percent of all projects in its pipeline include a residential component
column37: and eight of the nine new resorts scheduled to open this year will include residences for buyers who want to call Four Seasons their home. “It allows people to go from dating us to marrying us
column38: ” Mr. White said. In London
column39: for instance
column40: buyers looking to tie the knot with Four Seasons can do so at Twenty Grosvenor Square
column41: A Four Seasons Residence
column42: the hotelier’s new stand-alone project with 37 private residences
column43: a wine cellar
column44: spa
column45: pool
column46: game room and business center
column47: amid private landscaped gardens in the high-end Mayfair neighborhood. About a mile away
column48: the Residences at Mandarin Oriental Mayfair
column49: with 80 luxury apartments
column50: housekeeping and a rooftop bar
column51: are slated to open in 2021. Liam Bailey
column52: a partner and global head of research for Knight Frank
column53: said that when someone decides to buy overseas
column54: “you are stepping outside your comfort zone. People find that quite a big step to take.” By buying a home with
column55: say
column56: St. Regis or Ritz-Carlton
column57: “you buy into a global brand
column58: ” Mr. Bailey said
column59: one able to offer guidance on purchasing real estate in an unfamiliar country with unfamiliar tax laws and regulations. For those buying something that is still under construction
column60: it instills confidence that the developer will deliver a completed product. It also makes leaving easier. “You are buying management
column61: ultimately
column62: ” Mr. Bailey said. “When you lock up and leave and go back to your main residence
column63: you know the property is maintained and looked after. You know they are looking after who is coming in and going out.” Mr. White noted that buying an overseas home under the marquee of a familiar brand also assuages buyers who may be nervous about immersing themselves in a foreign culture. “Americans aren’t the most adventurous travelers in the world
column64: ” he said. “Safety and security are becoming more important.” The model has become so popular
column65: in fact
column66: that brands beyond hotels are also attaching their luxury images to residential developments. The Italian jeweler Bulgari now offers residences in London and Dubai. French crystal maker Baccarat operates 60 homes in its Manhattan hotel. Fashion house Fendi is developing 41 Fendi Private Residences in Scottsdale
column67: Ariz. At the Porsche Design Tower in Sunny Isles Beach
column68: Fla.
column69: residents can park their cars next to their apartments — even on the 50th floor. And just a few blocks away
column70: 260 luxury residences are nearing completion in the 60-story Armani Casa tower. All that comes at a price. “If you have two developments sitting side by side and one has a recognizable global brand
column71: it sells a bit faster
column72: and at a premium
column73: ” said Rod Taylor
column74: director of international residential developments for Savills London. “People are buying a brand they recognize. If they don’t know a town or a city very well
column75: but they see a Four Seasons or a Mandarin
column76: it gives them that warm
column77: comfy feeling that they can actually go ahead and buy.” Simon Jacobs
column78: an investor from Manhattan
column79: long considered buying a vacation home in the Caribbean
column80: but he didn’t know where. He was after something with a beachfront
column81: and that was reachable via nonstop flight. “I didn’t want to have to deal with any of the issues
column82: ” he said. After checking out possibilities in Anguilla
column83: St. Barts
column88: his wife Eliana and their two daughters found their dream island home during a Christmas 2015 stay at the Viceroy Sugar Beach
column89: a resort on an old sugar plantation on St. Lucia that offers privately owned
column90: one- to four-bedroom residences. “These new residences they were building were right on the beach and there weren’t dozens of them
column91: ” Mr. Jacobs said. They were set between the Piton mountains and the Caribbean Sea
column92: and he had “never seen anything that was that beautiful.” They could also be rented out through the Viceroy hotel system when the family wasn’t there. That May
column93: he paid about $8.25 million for one of the hotel’s five new contemporary beachfront residences
column95: 200-square-foot house with a double-height living and dining room
column96: a media room and a closet to store snorkeling gear. Since the house was completed a year ago
column98: who also have a weekend home in Connecticut and summer in Europe
column99: have only been there a few times. “You use it when you want it
column100: and when you don’t want it
column103: noting that the rent he collects offsets his homeowner fees. “You get income. You have no ownership cost.” The Jacobses plan to return at the end of February and again in late March. “It is rented through the summer
column104: ” Mr. Jacobs said. “It’s part investment and part nice to have a house to come to that’s your own.” Penny Strawson
column105: the property director of Sugar Beach Residences
column106: said many owners — typically those looking forward to retirement — rent out the houses “a great deal to start with and then use them more as they reach retirement. They made their return.” But as sales volume rises at branded communities
column107: the average age is falling. Mr. White
column110: ” spanning several generations. At resort properties
column111: multigenerational clients are important. “We will see a family buy a residence and bring the grandparents and kids along and use it as a vehicle to build a great legacy and memories
column113: the global head of acquisitions and development for Viceroy Resorts
column114: said condo hotels and resort residences started as a way “to help developers financially engineer their deals
column115: ” then “morphed into a very unique way to satisfy the needs of guests” who wanted to own homes. Viceroy is currently building residences at new resorts in Panama
column116: Portugal and Mexico. The communities “make it effortless for you to buy something
column117: ” Mr. Desai said. “You don’t have to worry about calling the landscaper.” Often
column118: buyers are looking for more than swimming pools and spas. The Four Seasons Palazzo Tornabuoni
column120: houses 37 apartments in a restored 16th-century palace in Florence
column122: and offers a calendar of lectures and events (wild boar hunting
column123: anyone?) “which you generally wouldn’t find in a residential complex in that location
column124: ” Mr. Bailey said. Homeowners also are offered tours to other cities and towns
column125: to help them engage with local culture. Tim Grisius
column126: the global real estate officer of Marriott
column130: W and 10 other luxury and premium brands
column131: said their residential business started about 20 years ago with a Ritz-Carlton residence conceived mostly as a way to grow the company’s hotel portfolio. Now
column133: “The residential business has become substantial enough that it has become a nice business on its own.” Marriott currently has 11 stand-alone residential projects in the works — from a Ritz-Carlton in Singapore to a St. Regis in Dubai and a Marriott in Cairo — as well as eight others in the pipeline. While the residential business used to be largely in the United States
column135: with 80 percent of the pipeline outside the U.S. “Globally
column136: we are seeing a significant portion of luxury hotels including a residential component because they work really well together
column137: ” Mr. Grisius said. When the Trump Organization launched its Trump International Realty brokerage in 2012
column138: its first project in South America was a luxury residential tower in Punta del Este
column139: a resort area in Uruguay. The building
column141: is not owned by Trump but will bear his brand. About 84 percent of about 160 units have been sold
column142: and the first condos are expected to close by the end of 2019
column145: the developer. The Trump Organization currently has 10 properties completed or in development
column146: according to a 2018 report on branded residences by Savills
column147: which lists the organization as the 11th-largest individual residence brand worldwide. As a wider range of brands enters the market
column148: offerings are also being expanded to include people who are not phenomenally wealthy. In 2017
column152: a 155-unit complex on the barrier reef of Belize’s Ambergris Caye
column153: part of the chain’s Autograph Collection. “I still want my sense of style
column154: but the power of the Marriott brand
column155: ” he said. “Everyone wants to own a piece of paradise
column157: “but it is a big decision to buy real estate offshore.” Slated to open next year
column158: the complex will include studios at $199
column165: 000 and eight beachfront villas priced at $1.3 million. Twenty-five percent of inventory is sold
column167: and 85 percent of the buyers are American. “If you go to more expensive markets
column169: $1.3 million will get you a one-bedroom in a tower
column171: “$1.3 million will get you a three-bedroom villa walking out onto the beach.” Four Seasons also has its eyes on Belize
column172: developing 85 residences as part of a new complex on Caye Chapel
column174: slated to open in 2021. Even as international locales explode in popularity
column176: the Savills report notes that the U.S. remains by far the largest market for branded residences
column177: with 32 percent of the globe’s supply. Four years ago
column178: Mark and Tori Smith of Denver purchased a 3
column180: three-bedroom condo for $3.5 million at the Dorado Beach Ritz-Carlton Reserve
column182: Puerto Rico. When Hurricane Maria hurtled toward the island two years later
column183: the Smiths left before it landed
column184: worried they might lose their investment. “I have never lived in an area where I had to worry about hurricanes
column187: the owner of a wealth management firm. “When this hurricane was coming
column188: my wife said this place is built to be bombproof. We lost two ceiling fans on the outside and some water in the windows
column189: but they didn’t break.” They got lucky. The resort suffered extensive damage and the hotel was closed for about a year
column190: but the residents were allowed back when utilities were restored. Last October
column191: Dorado Beach reopened with more than 300
column192: 000 new plantings and expanded facilities. Although the Smiths return to Denver every month
column193: they spend a total of five months and a day at the Dorado — the minimum required to call Puerto Rico their permanent residence. Mr. Smith said he would have been happy had they selected “a high-end condo with first class services
column194: ” but the Ritz-Carlton “has always carried a brand name in terms of quality and service and ambience. That had an appeal to us.” Advertisement

---split---4.0---split---https://www.wired.com/story/border-smart-wall-privacy-surveillance/---split---After years of promises about a physical wall stretching along the US-Mexico border, President Donald Trump declared a state of emergency last week in an attempt to secure wall funding in spite of congressional opposition. But physical barriers alone have always been both ineffective and expensive. And the constant debate around that singular aspect has distracted from a much more pressing issue: how the US can expand its use of technology for screening and enforcement at the border without overstepping already strained privacy rights. Border security technologies, like surveillance drones and biometric identity schemes, received funding in the most recent spending bill from Congress as an alternative to Trump's physical wall. But privacy advocates long have argued that a smart wall

column15: Hassan Shibly said. But Muthana was a vulnerable young woman who was brainwashed and manipulated by these criminal masterminds. They took advantage of her and used her

column18: Shibly said. She's asking that she can come and face our legal system and pay whatever debt she may have to society and speak out to ensure other people aren't trafficked and brainwashed and abused as she was." Trump has asked European countries to hold criminal proceedings for their own citizens that joined ISIS. But Pompeo said in a statement that Muthana is not a U.S. citizen and will not be admitted into the country. "She does not have any legal basis

column1: ---split---4.0---split---http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/01/08/border-apprehensions-of-migrant-families-have-risen-substantially-so-far-in-2018/---split---Numbers
column2: Facts and Trends Shaping Your World About Follow  By Kristen Bialik There were nearly 467
column3: 000 apprehensions at the U.S.-Mexico border in 2018
column4: the most for any calendar year since at least 2012
column5: according to a Pew Research Center analysis of the most recent available data from U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The increase was driven in part by a dramatic spike in border apprehensions of family members at the end of last year. Despite the increase
column6: the number of border apprehensions in 2018 remained far below the levels throughout most of the 1980s
column8: when around 1 million or more migrants were being apprehended each fiscal year. The situation at the southwest border has become the focus of the now nearly month-long partial federal government shutdown. President Donald Trump and Democratic congressional leaders are at an impasse over Trump’s proposal for a wall at the border. In the months leading up to the shutdown
column9: there was a large increase in the number of people in family units apprehended at the border. Monthly family apprehensions subsequently hit new highs each month from September through December
column10: according to data going back to 2012. There were nearly 17
column11: 000 family member apprehensions in September
column12: more than 23
column13: 000 in October
column14: about 25
column15: 000 in November and a record of more than 27
column16: 000 in December. All told
column17: roughly 163
column18: 000 family members were apprehended last year – more than three times as many as in 2017
column19: and the highest number since at least 2012.  Family members accounted for about a third (35%) of all border apprehensions in 2018 – the highest share within the past seven years. The months leading up to the shutdown drove this increase: Family member apprehensions in December made up more than half (54%) of total southwest border apprehensions that month
column20: the fourth consecutive high since September (40%). Border agents also apprehended nearly 54
column21: 000 unaccompanied children in 2018 – or 12% of the total – though this share was lower than in 2014 through 2016 (each 14%). (Unaccompanied child apprehensions do not include children who were apprehended as a family unit and later became unaccompanied as a result of prosecution initiatives.) Besides unaccompanied children and family members
column22: single adults continue to account for the largest share of border apprehensions: In 2018 there were nearly 250
column23: 000 single adult apprehensions
column24: or 54% of the total. Still
column25: the recent surge in family unit apprehensions is particularly notable because December 2018 marks the third time family member apprehensions exceeded single adult apprehensions
column26: according to the Department of Homeland Security. The other two times were in October and November. The apprehension of families and unaccompanied children received renewed attention following the Trump administration’s announcement of a “zero tolerance” policy in April last year. The policy led families to be separated at the border starting in May
column27: though Trump ended the policy in an executive order in late June. Family separations do still occur – such as when adult migrants traveling with children are apprehended at the border and deemed to be involved in criminal or gang activity – though more rarely than under the zero tolerance policy. From June 21 through November
column28: 81 children were separated from 76 adult family members at the border
column29: according to the Department of Homeland Security. The vast majority of immigrant families and unaccompanied minors apprehended on the U.S.-Mexico border come from Mexico or the Northern Triangle region (El Salvador
column30: Guatemala and Honduras). (In December 2018
column31: 95% of apprehended family members were from the Northern Triangle.) And in recent years
column32: there have been more overall apprehensions of non-Mexicans than Mexicans at U.S. borders
column33: reflecting a decline in the number of unauthorized Mexican immigrants coming to the U.S. over the past decade. Many families are leaving countries with high levels of violent crime
column34: a fact highlighted in 2017 by U.S. Vice President Mike Pence
column35: who said “vicious gangs and vast criminal organizations” drive illegal immigration to the U.S. In 2016
column36: El Salvador had the world’s highest murder rate (82.8 homicides per 10
column37: 000 people)
column38: followed by Honduras (at a rate of 56.5). Guatemala was 10th (at 27.3)
column39: according to data from the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime. Poverty represents another motivating force for migration from Central America. Northern Triangle nations are among the poorest in Latin America
column40: and although some have seen a reduction of extreme poverty in recent years
column41: high shares of people still live on less than $2 a day (the international poverty line is $1.90). Within Latin America and the Caribbean
column42: Honduras has the second-highest share (16%) of people below the international poverty line
column43: after Haiti (24%)
column44: according to the latest data from the World Bank. Guatemala is fourth-highest at 9%. In El Salvador
column45: 2% of people live below $2 a day. Given the level of poverty in the region
column46: some migrants seek out economic opportunity in the U.S. in hopes of sending money back to their home countries. Most remittance dollars flowing to Latin America come from the U.S.
column47: and for Northern Triangle countries in particular
column48: remittances make up a relatively large share of each country’s gross domestic product. In Honduras
column49: for example
column50: remittances were 19% of the nation’s GDP in 2017
column51: according to data from the World Bank. In comparison
column52: remittances were about 3% of Mexico’s GDP last year. For unaccompanied children
column53: family reunification could also be a strong driver. Among children from the Northern Triangle who were apprehended by the U.S. between January 2014 and April 2015
column54: 60% were released to a parent already living in the U.S. Fewer than 10% were released to a non-family sponsor
column55: such as a family friend or a person the family had no previous relationship with
column56: according to an analysis by the U.S. Government Accountability Office. Note: This is an update of a post originally published July 6
column57: 2018. Topics: Immigration Trends
column58: Global Migration and Demography
column59: Migration
column60: Immigration Kristen Bialik is a research assistant at Pew Research Center. Real-time analysis and news about data from Pew Research Center writers and social scientists. 1615 L St. NW
column61: Suite 800 Washington

column63: attitudes and trends shaping the world. It conducts public opinion polling
column64: demographic research
column65: media content analysis and other empirical social science research. Pew Research Center does not take policy positions. It is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts.

Education and income are linked to concern about climate change in South Africa: Those with more education or incomes higher than the median are more likely to see climate change as a major threat. Across the Middle Eastern
column154: sub-Saharan African and Latin American countries surveyed
column155: there are a variety of international concerns
column157: climate change and ISIS are seen as top threats. In both Tunisia and Israel
column158: ISIS is considered the top threat. Roughly eight-in-ten Tunisians (81%) see the militant Islamic group as a major threat. They are additionally apprehensive about the condition of the world economy
column159: cyberattacks and climate change. About six-in-ten (61%) also say U.S. power and influence are a major threat to their country. Israelis also see ISIS as the top international threat among those tested. However
column160: only 47% label it a major threat
column161: illustrating Israel’s relatively low level of concern about all threat items tested. Roughly four-in-ten see cyberattacks (42%) and climate change (38%) as pressing threats. Jewish Israelis are more likely than the country’s Arabs to be worried about North Korea’s nuclear program
column163: cyberattacks from other countries and the condition of the global economy. On the other hand
column164: Arabs are more likely to categorize U.S. power and influence as a large threat. Ideology also affects how Israelis perceive global threats. Israelis on the ideological right are more likely than those on the left to see North Korea’s nuclear program (42% vs. 21%) and ISIS (53% vs. 36%) as major threats. Those on the right are also less concerned about climate change (32% vs. 46%) and the condition of the global economy (35% vs. 49%) than are those on the left. Compared with concerns about Russian or Chinese influence
column165: worries about U.S. power and influence are relatively high in Argentina
column167: Mexico and Tunisia. More than half in these countries say U.S. power is a major threat to their country. By comparison
column168: concerns about the U.S. are relatively lower in sub-Saharan Africa and Israel. In none of these countries does a majority express concern about Russian or Chinese power. Apprehension about U.S. power has also increased over time in these countries. In Brazil
column170: concerns have gone up by more than 25 percentage points from 2013 to 2018. Worries have increased the least in Israel (up 6 points). Fact Tank01/17/2019 Fact Tank11/28/2018 Fact Tank09/06/2018 Social Trends01/17/2019 U.S. Politics01/18/2019 1615 L St. NW

column1: ---split---4.0---split---http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/02/21/immigrants-temporary-protected-status-in-us/---split---Numbers
column2: Facts and Trends Shaping Your World About Follow  By D’Vera Cohn
column3: Jeffrey S. Passel and Kristen Bialik Many immigrants who have time-limited permission to live and work in the United States under Temporary Protected Status (TPS) face an uncertain future as the White House and lawmakers from both parties wrangle over immigration policy and border security issues. Roughly 318
column4: 000 people currently have this protected status after fleeing their countries because of war
column5: hurricanes
column6: earthquakes or other extraordinary conditions that could make it dangerous for them to live in that country. Nearly all are expected to lose their benefits either this year or next. Federal officials have said that TPS is meant to provide temporary rather than long-term relief. The Trump administration proposed extending Temporary Protected Status for 300
column7: 000 immigrants as part of a border wall deal to end the longest government shutdown in history earlier this year. Democrats opposed the proposed plan for several reasons
column8: including new standards and higher fees for TPS applications. The Department of Homeland Security said last year that it would not extend Temporary Protected Status for immigrants from six of the 10 nations that are now eligible. Of those six nations
column9: five (Sudan
column10: Nicaragua
column11: Nepal
column12: Haiti and El Salvador) will face TPS expirations this year. TPS for Honduras expires in 2020. Only those from South Sudan
column13: Syria
column14: Yemen and Somalia have received TPS extensions with the possibility of future extension. However
column15: the decisions to end TPS for those from Sudan
column16: Nicaragua
column17: Haiti and El Salvador have been temporarily blocked by a federal court. And immigrant advocates recently filed a separate lawsuit challenging the decision to end TPS for those from Nepal and Honduras. The first groups expected to lose their benefits will be roughly 1
column18: 000 Sudanese and about 2
column19: 500 Nicaraguans whose benefits were extended through April 2 of this year. However
column20: their benefits will continue while the court injunction remains in effect. Benefits for the largest group
column21: about 195
column22: 000 people from El Salvador
column23: are scheduled to expire this September. In all
column24: immigrants with Temporary Protected Status were about 3% of the 10.7 million unauthorized immigrants living in the U.S. in 2016
column25: according to a Pew Research Center analysis of government data. Yet this share was higher for some countries: Immigrants with TPS accounted for about a quarter of unauthorized immigrants from El Salvador (27%) and around 13% of those from Honduras in 2016
column26: for example. (This analysis assumes that immigrants with TPS are in the U.S. without authorization.) Once the Department of Homeland Security designates a nation’s immigrants as eligible for Temporary Protected Status
column27: immigrants may apply if they entered the U.S. without authorization or entered on a temporary visa that has expired. Applicants may also have a valid temporary visa or another non-immigrant status such as foreign student. To be granted TPS
column28: applicants must meet filing deadlines
column29: pay a fee and prove they have lived in the U.S. continuously since the events that triggered relief from deportation. They also must meet criminal-record requirements – for example
column30: that they have not been convicted of any felony or two or more misdemeanors while in the U.S.
column31: or been engaged in persecuting others or terrorism. Temporary Protected Status does not make individuals automatically eligible for permanent residence or U.S. citizenship
column32: but some may apply for permanent lawful status. Federal officials are required to announce 60 days before any TPS designation expires whether it will be extended; without a decision
column33: it automatically extends six months. Here is the status for the largest origin groups now protected under TPS
column34: based on the most recent Federal Register notices for each country: EL SALVADOR In 2016
column35: there were 725
column36: 000 unauthorized immigrants from El Salvador living in the U.S.
column37: and about a quarter of these (27%) had Temporary Protected Status
column38: according to Pew Research Center estimates. As of 2018
column39: U.S. government officials estimate that 195
column40: 000 individuals from El Salvador have TPS
column41: which is scheduled to expire on Sept. 9. Though the Trump administration plans not to extend TPS for Salvadorans
column42: this decision has been temporarily blocked by a federal court. The current TPS for El Salvador applies to immigrants who have lived in the U.S. since Feb. 13
column44: following a series of earthquakes that killed more than a thousand people and inflicted widespread damage. Recovery has been slowed by a series of problems
column45: including “hurricanes and tropical storms
column46: heavy rains and flooding
column47: volcanic and seismic activity
column48: an ongoing coffee rust [fungus disease] epidemic
column49: and a prolonged regional drought that is impacting food security
column50: ” according to a Federal Register notice explaining why the designation has repeatedly been extended. The notice also cited increasing violence and high unemployment. El Salvador’s government has asked that TPS be extended. HAITI There were about 100
column51: 000 unauthorized immigrants from Haiti in the U.S. in 2016 overall
column52: according to the Center’s estimates. U.S. government officials estimate about 46
column53: 000 Haitian immigrants have Temporary Protected Status as of 2018. TPS benefits for Haitians are set to expire July 22
column54: with no plans for extension
column55: though the Trump administration’s decision to terminate TPS is also temporarily blocked by a federal court challenge. The TPS designation for Haiti was based on an earthquake that killed hundreds of thousands of people in January 2010. Immigrants also are eligible if they entered the U.S. up to a year later – so any Haitian immigrant with protected status has been in the U.S. since at least early 2011. In 2017
column56: the Haitian government asked for an 18-month extension leading up to the July 22 termination
column57: citing recent catastrophes including other hurricanes. HONDURAS and NICARAGUA There are 57
column58: 000 Hondurans and roughly 2
column59: 550 Nicaraguans with Temporary Protected Status
column60: as of 2018 estimates. In 2016
column61: there were an estimated 425
column62: 000 unauthorized immigrants from Honduras and around 70
column63: 000 from Nicaragua overall. Benefits expire for Nicaraguans (as well as for Sudanese) on April 2
column64: with no plans for extension
column65: though this is being challenged in court along with terminations for El Salvador and Haiti. Benefits for Hondurans expire Jan. 5
column67: with no plans for extension. Immigrants from Honduras and Nicaragua who qualify for TPS must have been living in the U.S. as of Dec. 30
column68: 1998. Immigrants from both countries were designated eligible for TPS based on damage from Hurricane Mitch in 1998. The storm killed more than 5
column69: 600 people in Honduras and more than 3
column70: 000 in Nicaragua. The government of Honduras had also requested an extension of TPS. Damage in Honduras was at least $5 billion
column71: and recovery has been hampered by tropical storms
column72: drought and poverty
column73: federal officials said when they last extended the TPS designation. In Nicaragua
column74: damage was at least $1.3 billion
column75: with a series of environmental disasters – including storms
column76: earthquakes and a volcanic eruption – getting in the way of recovery efforts
column77: federal officials said in extending that country’s TPS designation. Elaine Duke
column78: then acting secretary of the Department of Homeland Security
column79: said in a 2017 announcement that conditions in Nicaragua had improved enough that the TPS designation would be terminated in January 2019
column80: but that was later pushed back as a result of an injunction by a U.S. District Court. Because of data limitations
column81: Pew Research Center has not estimated the TPS share of unauthorized immigrants from the other six countries. They include Nepal (with 8
column82: 950 immigrants with TPS)
column83: Somalia (500)
column89: 250). Congress and President George H.W. Bush authorized the TPS program in the 1990 immigration law
column90: granting the White House executive power to designate and extend the status to immigrants in the U.S. based on certain criteria. Note: This is an update of a post originally published Nov. 8
column91: 2017. For the most recent information on Temporary Protected Status by country
column92: see the Department of Homeland Security TPS page. Topics: Unauthorized Immigration

column1: ---split---5.0---split---https://www.nbcnews.com/think/opinion/forget-subpoenaing-trump-officials-house-democrats-can-just-let-trump-ncna974041---split---As the White House increasingly uses executive privilege to shield themselves from cooperating with congressional investigations
column2: whistleblowers will be key to unlocking the secrets of what is really happening inside the Trump Administration. That became more evident this week
column3: when “credible information” provided by multiple whistleblowers concerning the White House’s efforts to “rush the transfer of highly sensitive U.S. nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia” led the House Committee on Oversight and Reform to announce a new investigation. According to an interim staff report
column4: the whistleblowers expressed “significant concerns about the potential procedural and legal violations connecting with rushing through a plan to transfer nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia.” and “conflicts of interest among top White House advisors.” They additionally “warned about political appointees ignoring directives from top ethics advisors at the White House who repeatedly and unsuccessfully ordered senior Trump Administration officials to halt their efforts.” Make no mistake about it
column5: these whistleblowers are risking their livelihoods and careers because they believe our national security is being put in jeopardy. The bulk of our foreign policy decisions and alliances are driven by where nuclear technology is deployed and
column6: in a region as politically unstable as the Middle East
column7: there would be significant geopolitical consequences from a decision that allows Saudi Arabia to make advancements in nuclear technology with the blessing of the U.S. government. This is a decision that warrants as much transparency as possible given what is at stake globally. Congressional investigators have thus been given specific dates
column8: documents
column9: information and names of White House officials engaged in what the whistleblowers believe problematic activities related to the potential transfer of nuclear technology to Iran. Those documents call into question the interactions and activities of the Trump Administration’s most senior members — including Jared Kushner
column10: energy secretary Rick Perry
column11: former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn (who pled guilty in 2017 to lying to the FBI)
column12: former Deputy National Security Advisor K.T. McFarland
column13: the inaugural committee chairman Thomas Barrack
column14: and President Trump’s former Deputy Campaign Manager and deputy chairman of the inaugural committee Rick Gates (who has also pled guilty in the Mueller investigation). It seems highly irregular to have political figureheads like Barrack play such a hands-on role in high-stakes foreign policy decisions. The report reveals that
column15: while serving as the national security advisor during Donald Trump’s campaign
column16: General Michael Flynn advocated for the adoption of a plan — initiated by a private company called IP3 — for them to build a nuclear plant in Saudi Arabia. Flynn
column17: though
column18: had simultaneously served as an advisor to an IP3 subsidiary and traveled to Saudi Arabia on behalf of IP3 (a trip he omitted from his security clearance application). Flynn’s support for the plan would continue throughout the presidential transition and after he joined the White House as the President’s National Security Advisor. Despite warnings about potential criminal conflicts of interest from National Security Council ethics and legal advisors
column19: the White House continued to move forward with Flynn’s plan
column20: even after he’d been forced out over concerns about his contacts with Russian officials and the veracity of his accounts of those contacts with Vice President Pence. In a new letter from Chairman Cummings to Acting WH Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney
column21: questions are raised regarding a February 12
column22: 2019 White House meeting in which the President reportedly expressed his support for transferring nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia — a meeting that “was initiated by IP3 International.” And next week
column23: Kushner — who
column24: again
column25: is named one of the people problematically involved in the potential transfer of nuclear technology — is scheduled to embark on a tour of the Middle East
column26: including Saudi Arabia. Kushner
column27: you may recall
column28: offered Saudi’s crown prince advice about how to weather the public relations storm after Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi was murdered at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul at the alleged order of the crown prince. Even more troubling are the potential financial conflicts of interest that Kushner has that pose troubling questions surrounding his motives for being so willing to help the crown prince. As the committee’s interim report points out
column29: in January of 2018
column30: Brookfield Business Partners announced plans to acquire Westinghouse Electric
column31: a bankrupt nuclear services company. This company is a key component of IP3’s efforts to build nuclear reactors in Saudi Arabia. Then
column32: in August of 2018
column33: BBP’s parent company
column34: Brookfield Asset Management
column35: purchased a partnership stake in 666 Fifth Avenue
column36: a building owned by Jared Kushner’s family company. Kushner reportedly divested his interest in this property when he joined his father-in-law’s administration
column37: but his interactions with foreign officials in the Middle East — particularly as his family looked for a financial backer — are
column38: at the very least
column39: highly irregular. As Congressman Ted Lieu tweeted this week
column40: “WHY DOES JARED KUSHNER STILL HAVE A SECURITY CLEARANCE?” That is
column41: one suspects
column42: a question that House Democrats are quite likely to try and answer — and they seem to be getting help. For all the media focus on the new Democratic majority’s subpoena powers
column43: the role of whistleblowers within the federal government could become the most important intelligence gathering asset for congressional investigators. Kurt Bardella is an NBC News THINK contributor and served as the spokesperson and senior advisor for the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee from 2009-2013. © 2019 NBC UNIVERSAL

column1: ---split---5.0---split---https://www.nbcnews.com/think/opinion/trump-s-attacks-first-amendment-press-gain-ally-supreme-court-ncna973431---split---As part of his broader assault on the news media
column2: President Donald Trump has repeatedly called for a revisiting of American libel law — part of the law of defamation
column3: which governs when individuals can sue those who have allegedly made false statements about them. On Tuesday
column4: he found a powerful ally in Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas
column5: who penned an opinion encouraging his colleagues to revisit the court’s landmark 1964 ruling in New York Times v. Sullivan. The Sullivan case is one of the most important Supreme Court decisions interpreting the First Amendment’s guarantee of freedom speech. By encouraging its demise
column6: Thomas is not only proposing to arm Trump with a legal mechanism for going after his critics
column7: he is also arguing that publicly criticizing public figures should come with far more risk. Although no other justice joined in his solo opinion
column8: Thomas’s analysis suggests that Trump’s attacks on the press are resonating in some of the most important chambers of government — and will only embolden new lawsuits seeking to weaken Sullivan and the critical constitutional principle that it articulated. Although no other justice joined in his solo opinion
column9: Thomas’s analysis suggests that Trump’s attacks on the press are resonating. The Sullivan decision came as part-and-parcel of the civil rights movement. On March 29
column11: civil rights groups took out a full-page “editorial” advertisement in the New York Times criticizing unnamed authorities in Montgomery
column12: Alabama
column13: for violating the Constitution by abusing protestors and various other actions. L.B. Sullivan
column14: a city commissioner
column15: sued the Times
column16: arguing that the advertisement defamed the reputation of the Montgomery police and included a few minor errors — such as suggesting that Dr. Martin Luther King
column17: Jr.
column18: had been arrested seven times (as opposed to four). Alabama libel law at the time forced defendants to prove their statements were true
column19: instead of presuming them true. Because the Times couldn’t prove that every statement in the advertisement was true
column20: the jury ruled in Sullivan’s favor
column21: and awarded $500
column22: 000 in damages. SIGN UP FOR THE THINK WEEKLY NEWSLETTER HERE In a sweeping opinion by Justice William Brennan
column23: Jr.
column24: the Supreme Court unanimously reversed this verdict. As Brennan explained
column25: “we consider this case against the background of a profound national commitment to the principle that debate on public issues should be uninhibited
column26: robust
column27: and wide-open
column28: and that it may well include vehement
column29: caustic
column30: and sometimes unpleasantly sharp attacks on government and public officials.” It may also include errors
column31: Brennan explained
column32: because “erroneous statement is inevitable in free debate.” But to allow states to punish all errors in statements about the official conduct of public figures would be antithetical to the purpose of the First Amendment
column33: because “[w]hatever is added to the field of libel is taken from the field of free debate.” In other words
column34: the Supreme Court believed that the extent to which the First Amendment shielded false speech about public officials was worth it compared to the far greater cost of chilling all Americans
column35: and not just the press
column36: from criticizing their government. This self-censorship was a natural outgrowth of the fear that even factually accurate criticisms could provoke costly litigation. That didn’t mean that a public official could never successfully sue for defamation. As Brennan explained
column37: there would be no First Amendment defense if the official could show “actual malice” on the defendant’s part — “that is
column38: with knowledge that it was false or with reckless disregard of whether it was false or not.” But the burden must be on the public official to demonstrate such malice
column39: rather than on the defendant to show good faith. Sullivan set forth a ringing defense of the right to criticize government officials and other public figures
column40: even if it sometimes came at the expense of truth. In the process
column41: Sullivan set forth a ringing defense of the right to criticize government officials and other public figures
column42: even if it sometimes came at the expense of truth. And although the decision’s protections were not limited to the press
column43: it was no accident that what followed was far more active — and skeptical — press coverage of national events
column44: from civil rights demonstrations to the Vietnam War to Watergate
column45: and beyond. As one media law scholar noted in 2017
column46: Sullivan “recognized that a free press
column47: however imperfect
column48: is the lifeblood of a healthy democracy
column49: one in which journalists are both benefactors and beneficiaries of the First Amendment — protecting and relying on its freedoms to inform their communities and enable democratic participation.” Thomas’s argument against Sullivan comes in a strange context — a civil suit against Bill Cosby by one of the women who accused him of sexual assault. The accuser
column50: Kathrine McKee
column51: claimed that Cosby’s attorney had
column52: at Cosby’s behest
column53: written and leaked a letter that defamed her reputation. The lower courts held that her claim could not proceed because McKee was a public figure under Sullivan
column54: and she could not satisfy the “actual malice” standard. Thomas did not dispute the core issue in the case — whether McKee was properly held to be a public figure. Rather
column55: he wrote to suggest that
column56: in a different case
column57: the court should revisit Sullivan itself
column58: a “policy-driven decision[] masquerading as constitutional law.” At the core of Thomas’s argument is what he claims to be the original understanding of the First Amendment — that the law of defamation was almost entirely left to state legislatures and state courts
column59: and the First Amendment did not create any special rules for cases involving public figures. Sullivan itself
column60: though
column61: highlighted the widespread and contemporary consensus that the deeply controversial Sedition Act of 1798 — which criminalized criticism of the federal government — was a violation of the First Amendment. These critics of the Sedition Act were Founders themselves — James Madison
column62: Thomas Jefferson
column63: etc. So one can draw a straight line
column64: as Brennan did
column65: from hostility to the Sedition Act to the need for an actual malice standard for defamation against public figures. Thus
column66: although Thomas may be right that “constitutional opposition to the Sedition Act... does not necessarily support a constitutional actual-malice rule in all civil libel actions brought by public figures
column67: ” it does underscore the broader point that the First Amendment protects
column68: and has always protected
column69: a right to criticize the government. Requiring public figures to demonstrate “actual malice” is merely the application of that right in the specific context of defamation law. To be clear
column70: no other justice joined in Thomas’s opinion
column71: and none of the current justices have previously expressed similar misgivings about Sullivan. Thus
column72: Sullivan may not be in jeopardy. But it’s impossible to disentangle Thomas’s opinion from the current political moment — from a president who has repeatedly attacked the media and derided as “fake news” coverage that is accurate but unflattering
column73: has specifically railed against libel laws and has suggested the time is ripe to “open [the laws] up” so that when the press “write purposely negative and horrible and false articles
column74: we can sue them and win lots of money.” For a justice who has been on the court for 27 years
column75: it is therefore an especially ominous moment to publicly suggest revisiting Sullivan — and troubling evidence that Trump’s efforts to weaken public support for our current libel regime
column76: and for the right to criticize the government it enshrines
column77: may well be working. Even at the highest levels of the judiciary. Steve Vladeck (@steve_vladeck) is a professor of law at the University of Texas School of Law whose teaching and research focus on federal jurisdiction
column78: constitutional law
column79: and national security law. Steve is co-editor-in-chief of the Just Security blog (@just_security) and co-host of the National Security Law Podcast (@nslpodcast). © 2019 NBC UNIVERSAL

column1: ---split---5.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/one-house-republican-jumped-join-democratic-effort-stop-donald-trumps-border-wall-national-emergency---split---Rep. Joaquin Castro
column2: D-Texas
column3: is leading the joint resolution of disapproval. (Tom Williams/CQ Roll Call) About an hour before an announced deadline for original co-sponsors on a Democratic-led effort to disapprove of President Donald Trump’s declaration of a national emergency over border security
column4: one Republican had signed on. At the same time
column5: the measure had already gathered support from 216 members
column6: almost all of them members of the House Democratic caucus. That’s according to the office of Rep. Joaquin Castro
column7: a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and is spearheading the joint resolution. It wasn’t immediately clear which GOP lawmaker had signed on early. Castro announced his intention Feb. 14
column8: and Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday night called on House members to back his effort. In a Dear Colleague letter
column9: the California Democrat said the measure would move “swiftly” through the chamber
column10: following the legal framework for expedited consideration under the National Emergencies Act. The Pelosi letter specified a 3 p.m. Thursday deadline for the initial round of co-sponsorships before Castro files the legislation on Friday
column11: when the House is scheduled to meet in a pro-forma session. The law provides a path for Congress to weigh in to reject a presidential emergency declaration
column12: but the joint resolution would need either a presidential signature or a two-thirds vote in each chamber to eventually override a Trump veto. “All Members take an oath of office to support and defend the Constitution. The President’s decision to go outside the bounds of the law to try to get what he failed to achieve in the constitutional legislative process violates the Constitution and must be terminated
column13: ” Pelosi wrote. “We have a solemn responsibility to uphold the Constitution
column14: and defend our system of checks and balances against the President’s assault.” The text of Castro’s resolution appears to be “clean
column15: ” meaning it should get expedited consideration in the Senate as well
column16: where it would have a chance of passage without needing 60 votes to break a filibuster. “Historically
column17: Presidents have declared national emergencies for urgent matters of national security. President Trump would unconstitutionally usurp congressional authority by declaring an emergency based upon unfounded hype rather than any substantive emergency
column18: ” Castro said in a statement last week
column19: announcing his potential plan just a day before Trump actually made the declaration And the effort to stop the use of an emergency declaration to seize funds for construction of the wall at the border with Mexico should get at least some Republican support in the Senate
column20: including from Sen. Susan Collins of Maine. “If the House passes a resolution of disapproval and it is a clean resolution
column21: I will support that
column22: ” Collins told reporters in South Portland on Wednesday. “There have been many of my colleagues on the Republican side who are very wary of the president’s actions because they don’t want a future Democratic president reallocating funds.” Collins said is also supportive of the separate legal action being taking by 16 states to try to stop the emergency declaration
column23: according to the Portland Press-Herald. There’s been some skepticism on both sides of the Capitol about Trump’s attempted end-run around the usual restrictions of the appropriations process. Sen. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee was perhaps most direct
column24: but the Energy-Water subcommittee chairman was not alone. “It is inconsistent with the U.S. Constitution because
column25: after the American Revolution against a king
column26: our founders chose not to create a chief executive with the power to tax the people and spend their money any way he chooses
column27: ” Alexander had said in a statement. “The Constitution gives that authority exclusively to a Congress elected by the people.” In a statement
column28: Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer said that a Senate companion to the joint resolution would be coming. “If the president’s emergency declaration prevails
column29: it will fundamentally change the balance of powers in a way our country’s founders never envisioned. That should be a serious wake up call to senators in both parties who believe in the constitutional responsibility of Congress to limit an overreaching executive
column30: ” the New York Democrat said. Get breaking news alerts and more from Roll Call on your iPhone or your Android. THE SOURCE FOR NEWS ON CAPITOL HILL SINCE 1955 Want insight more often?  Get Roll Call in your inbox  ×

column1: ---split---5.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/congress/congress-to-subpoena-full-mueller-report-if-ag-barr-withholds-parts-blumenthal-says---split---Sen. Richard Blumenthal
column2: D-Conn.
column3: has said Congress will subpoena the Mueller report if the Justice Department does not publicize it. (Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call file photo) Democrats in Congress will subpoena the full report of special counsel Robert S. Mueller III if the Justice Department only discloses certain parts of it
column4: Sen. Richard Blumenthal said Thursday. The Connecticut Democrat is a key member of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina is the committee’s chairman
column5: and has subpoena power over the Justice Department. CNN reported Wednesday that Mueller could issue a report on Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. elections as early as next week
column6: though the special counsel’s notoriously tight-lipped office has provided no timeline for its plans. [Brett Kavanaugh could decide how redistricting is done] Newly confirmed Attorney General William Barr was noncommittal in his confirmation hearing about whether he would allow Mueller to testify before Congress
column7: and whether he would resist a subpoena for the special counsel’s report. Blumenthal told CNN’s “New Day” that he is optimistic Graham would join Democrats in the House in subpoenaing the Mueller report. Democratic Chairman Jerrold Nadler of the House Judiciary Committee has said the full report should be made public. “There’ll be subpoenas from Congress
column8: including
column9: I hope
column10: from the Senate Judiciary Committee
column11: ” Blumenthal said. Nadler echoed that sentiment last month. [3 Takeaways: There’s a big 2020 hue within Trump’s anti-socialism push] “If necessary
column12: our committee will subpoena the report. If necessary
column13: we’ll get Mueller to testify
column14: “ the New York Democrat told CNN in January. “The American people need the information here.” Shielding most of Mueller’s report
column15: and issuing select bits and pieces
column16: would create the “public perception of a cover-up
column17: ” Blumenthal warned Thursday. “If William Barr believes — I think he does — that a sitting president cannot be indicted — I disagree with him — and he brings no charges that Mueller says can’t be brought
column18: and if there are no public disclosures
column19: the public rightly will feel that there is a cover-up

column9: the bear has kept the mood pretty chill. “It seems silly
column10: to dress up as a big animal
column11: ” said Snape
column12: who shares bear duties with other employees of the nonprofit Center for Biological Diversity
column13: where he works as senior counsel. “But what I discovered is that wearing this huge outfit is just a magnet. It inspires almost any person of any type to want to engage and talk.” The message is simple: If glaciers keep melting at the current pace
column14: polar bears won’t make it to the end of the century. Or as Snape puts it
column15: “Frostpaw is completely and utterly screwed if we don’t address climate change. The only polar bears left will be in zoos and dorks like me wearing outfits.” So why doesn’t Frostpaw make it to the Capitol more often? The bear has ventured inside for a hearing or two
column16: but logistics make it difficult. Getting the bulky costume through security is a challenge
column17: and Snape sees the character as primarily an educational tool rather than a lobbying one. That’s not to say the bear won’t be showing up in support of the Green New Deal. “Frostpaw’s new hero is Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
column18: ” according to Snape. Some climate activists have turned up the volume in the Trump era
column19: especially after the president withdrew from the Paris climate deal and cast doubt on his administration’s finding that extreme temperatures and rising sea levels could hurt Americans. But Frostpaw has stuck to a low-key script. “I don’t go around saying
column20: ‘Trump sucks
column21: ’ even though Frostpaw doesn’t like Trump very much. That’s not a good message
column22: ” said Snape
column23: who also teaches classes at American University’s law school. “Frostpaw would have to turn into a very angry bear
column24: and we’ve decided not to make that turn yet.” Instead
column25: Snape wants people to see his bear costume and think of the future. That much
column26: at least
column27: doesn’t have to be partisan
column28: he said. “Even at the Republican National Convention in 2016
column29: after Trump had already said climate change is a ‘hoax
column30: ’ I cannot tell you the number of Republicans who’d come up and say
column31: ‘We love you
column32: Frostpaw. We’ll do something to save you.’” Trump: Green New Deal sounds like a ‘high school term paper that got a low mark’ Get breaking news alerts and more from Roll Call on your iPhone or your Android. column1: ---split---6.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/congress/congress-block-big-chunk-trumps-emergency-wall-money---split---More than a third of the money President Donald Trump wants to redirect from other federal programs to build a border barrier is likely to be unavailable from the sources he identified. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images file photo) More than one-third of the money President Donald Trump wants to redirect from other federal programs to build a border barrier is likely to be unavailable from the sources he has identified. As a result
column2: it may be difficult for the president to circumvent Congress
column3: even if a resolution disapproving of his “emergency” moves is never enacted. Trump announced Feb. 15 that
column4: using emergency powers
column5: he wants to divert as much as $6.7 billion from other programs to finance the construction of barriers along the U.S.-Mexico border. That includes $3.6 billion from unspent military construction money
column6: $2.5 billion in unspent Pentagon counterdrug funds and $600 million from a Treasury Department asset forfeiture account. But the Defense Department has told lawmakers that only $85 million remains unspent in the counterdrug account
column7: a House Appropriations spokesman said Thursday. The Pentagon is planning to ask Congress for authority to reprogram more than $2.4 billion from other military programs into the counterdrug account in order to then take it right back out and move it to the wall project. “The Department would need to reprogram additional funding into the account to reach the up to $2.5 billion that may be required for border security support
column8: ” said Christopher Sherwood
column9: a Defense Department spokesman. Flashback: Trump announces national emergency on border
column10: despite likely legal challenge However
column11: a reprogramming request must be approved by both Republicans and Democrats on the four authorizing and appropriating panels that oversee the Pentagon. Such approval in this case is all but certain to fail. All it would take is one chairman or ranking member to say no. On Thursday
column12: one of those lawmakers
column13: Indiana Democrat Peter J. Visclosky
column14: chairman of the House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee
column15: said in a statement that he would turn down any request to reprogram military money to pay for a border wall. “I am adamantly opposed to the use of any funds provided by Congress to the Department of Defense for the unauthorized construction of a wall on the Southwest border
column16: ” Visclosky said. “I and the other members of the House Appropriations Committee will carefully examine each element of the President’s proposal and the serious jurisdictional and Constitutional concerns that it raises.” The $2.5 billion comprises about 37 percent of the money Trump wants to redirect to the border initiative and away from its congressionally approved purposes. Trump could still find other ways to pay for the project against Congress’ wishes
column17: including adding to the amount of military construction money he will tap. According to a House Appropriations Committee spreadsheet
column18: there appears to be some billions of dollars in previously appropriated but unobligated military construction money that could be available to be redirected from the projects the military and Congress approved. The Pentagon has yet to announce which military construction projects it will tap to bankroll this year’s installment of wall money. The additional border barriers could eventually cost an estimated $25 billion. Some on Capitol Hill say they are bracing for another possibility: that the president could move money as he wishes in the Pentagon budget and just disregard the traditional requirement that a president must get congressional approval for shifting sizable amounts of money from one account to another.
